displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: I mean, again, if he takes them, he may eat less, but – um. Family Member: Are they just loaded with caffeine or something or? Doctor: Some of them are. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, when we saw you or you had came on April seventeenth, your white count was normal. You are anemic. I don’t think it’s really the iron. It may be your cancer and your treatment. It’s twenty-nine. Normal would be forty-one. Uh, and your platelets are okay. So, the only thing that we see is the low, uh, blood count, blood cells. Um. Your liver looks good. (Pause) Patient: I was on chemo ‘til February? Maybe that’s why the blood count’s down. I don’t know. (Pause) Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec)

Patient: Sure. Doctor: For things. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s uh technology moves on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so does your cancer. So that profile will look different after we give chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So new things might pop up. Patient: Okay. And I had some other questions Doctor: Yeah. Patient: about other clinical trial options. Doctor: Oh, yeah, there’s zillions. We are not gonna run out. (& PAT high five each other) Patient: Well yeah, it is.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: She has to talk to other people. Doctor: No swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Great. Okay. Patient: I have these, I had these little under-the-skin cysts for about ages. (pause4sec) Doctor: Okay, so today, your white count’s normal. You’re, you’re not anemic, and your platelets are normal. Your, uh, electrolytes, your sugar is on the high side at one twenty-one. Uh, did you have breakfast today? Patient: I did. Doctor: Yeah, so it’s- Patient: Yeah, I, I, when they, they said I had phlebotomy, I asked if it was fasting, and they said “No.” So, I, uh, ate breakfast. Doctor: And your PSA today is twenty-two. Patient: Ouch. Doctor: That’s all good. And your testosterone is (pause6sec) Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings)

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: So that there’s no misunderstanding. Patient: Sure, okay, okay. On the um on that biopsy result, Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: anything of any significance? Doctor: No I mean you have I think the P10 mutation which will be helpful for us because we have a study that actually targets that group of folks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yep so that’s already on deck. And you know the thing is as time moves on you will get that test repeated so that’s good for that moment in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But after chemo that profile will change again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we will most likely do both. We’ll check your tissue and we now also check your circulating blood. Patient: Sure.

Patient: Yeah. We ran into it. Doctor: I don’t know what happened. Somebody tried, I don’t know if it was a suicide case or something but they blocked all the lanes or something was going on. Family Member: Yeah. I heard about that earlier today. Doctor: Something was going on so everybody was all discombobulated today. Family Member: It was north and south going into Ohio. Doctor: Yeah. That’s what it was. That was what it was. A little scary. Family Member: Yeah. I saw that this morning. Doctor: Oh, my. Family Member: North and south was shut down. Doctor: Oh, boy. Patient: No south of us Doctor: Yeah. It was police incident. I’m not sure exactly what they say it was but-

Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh… Doctor: I think you might need surgery to fix that problem. Patient: A surgeon? Doctor: Yeah a urologist. Patient: That sounds like fun. laughs]] Doctor: I know. Laughs]] Well it’s better than constantly dealing with this pestering problem. Family Member: The pestering is what it is.

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing. Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it?

Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way. Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday?

Patient: Both sides, and - Doctor: All right. Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Still having constipation issues? Come and go? Patient: Of course (chuckles) Doctor: Okay, so with the chemo now, the things to keep track of any kind of fevers, infections, anything I need to know right away. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Now what’s the best way to - Doctor: Get in touch with me? So one-eight hundred_____. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And you ask them to page me. Family Member: All right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: How, how long have you been home now? Patient: Two days or- Family Member: Three days. Doctor: From S___’s. Yes. So I, I need you to be two weeks, walking around, not back in the hospital, fully recovered- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Until we can go and talk about that. No rush. Plus your next shot I think is April fourth. So we may uh, you know, we’ll work on that, but you may even be, you come in at the same time, and we can use that same visit. So I’ll look at that. Okay? Any questions? Patient: I didn’t know that you - So that’s what I had? I had cancer, I mean, uh, I had pneumonia and-? Doctor: Pneumonia and the flu. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: The flu? Yeah. That’s what I had before. Doctor: Yeah. I think that’s what happened when I talked to your doctor. They were for sure about pneumonia. They were waiting on the flu results at the time. But I think they treated you like you had the flu, anyway, so. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk.

Patient: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: Okay. Alright so I think we’re gonna have to contact you back (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: …correctly for you then we have to switch to a different medicine. Okay. So go ahead and stop the Casodex. Okay? Patient: The - The Casodex I don’t – don’t take the Casodex? Doctor: Do you have enough for the next month or so? Patient: Right now I have about, I probably got about a week left of that before they re… Doctor: Okay perfect. Don’t refill it. Patient: Okay, but just take… Doctor: Until I figure this out. Patient: But just take the rest of those?

Family Member: Oh, oh, he can? Doctor: Yeah. It’s only those four days. Family Member: OOH! It’s the first of the week of the week that you get it. Doctor: Of the week you get it, I don’t want you on the plane Thursday through Sunday. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of the time you’re free. So you can go on the twenty-sixth. If you go on the eighth you can go; if you have chemo on the eighth you can go. Patient: Well when would my next day? Is it monthly or is it weekly? Doctor: It’s every three weeks. Patient: It’s every three weeks. Doctor: You’ll be fine. Patient: Okay, perfect. Doctor: And we can Patient: So when I get it on the eighth in terms of my work schedule; I’m an attorney; if I have a trial like the ninth or the tenth, can I -
